awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Polar Coding for Data Storage: Theory and Applications
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
Data storage technology is vitally important in our daily lives, affecting individuals, businesses, and government organizations. In particular, hard-disk drives and solid-state drives are ubiquitous in cell phones, tablets, and computers of all sizes, found in homes, businesses, and large data centers. All these storage devices make use of sophisticated data encoding methods in order to ensure that the stored information can be retrieved reliably. Such methods include error-correction codes that actively recover from device impairments which would otherwise cause catastrophic data-retrieval errors, as well as other types of coding that preemptively avoid certain particularly vulnerable patterns of data.

Storage systems are usually modeled as communication channels, for which coding-theoretic progress is continually sought. Polar codes, discovered in 2009 by Erdal Arikan, are universally recognized as a major breakthrough in coding theory. Polar codes provably achieve the channel capacity -- the information-theoretic limit on the rate at which information can be reliably transmitted -- on a large class of channels. They also offer low encoding and decoding complexity. Nevertheless, many challenges remain in introducing polar codes into the engineering practice of data-storage systems and devices.

This project focused on advancing our theoretical understanding of polar codes, exploring system architectures that incorporate polar coding into storage devices, and realizing these architectures in high-speed low-power VLSI circuits.

Here is a summary of our main theoretical findings. The construction of polar codes makes use of a matrix called a kernel. Arikan?s polar codes are based upon a simple 2-by-2 kernel, but subsequent research has shown that larger, l-by-l kernels, can lead to better performance. We have identified certain kernels that lead to faster convergence to channel capacity, as a function of codeword length, than previously known polar codes. Later, we developed an efficient decoding algorithm for large kernels that can be expressed as permutations of the Arikan kernel. We have also answered a fundamental theoretical question, showing that polar codes can approach capacity under the best possible scaling of their block length as a function of the gap to capacity. Other theoretical results include the development of decoding algorithms for polar codes on channels with deletions, improved methods for understanding the ordering of encoded bit positions in terms of their reliability, and a universal polar coding scheme for asymmetric channels. For applications, we developed capacity-achieving polar codes for memories with defects and extended a capacity-achieving rate-compatible polar code construction to more general families of codes and channels. We have also examined architectures suitable for incorporating polar codes in magnetic recording channels with intersymbol interference.

We furthermore made significant progress related to the implementation of polar codes in practical systems. Of the many methods to improve polar code performance, list decoding combined with cyclic-redundancy-check pre-coding gives the best results. This approach, developed by one of the investigators on this project and incorporated into the new 5G wireless communication standard, requires new decoding architectures. In this project, we developed an algorithm that improves the speed and throughput of list decoding. We have implemented this algorithm first in software and then in hardware. We have also developed low-complexity encoding and decoding methods for systematic polar codes of different lengths.

Evaluation of polar code performance can be done experimentally but this is laborious and time-consuming.  It is therefore important to develop mathematical models for the storage channel that can be used to numerically evaluate code effectiveness. We used measured error characteristics of multilevel flash memories to develop a statistical model that captures key features of memory error distributions. This model was shown to predict actual measured polar code error performance better than previous channel models.

Our research naturally led to the consideration of other data detection and coding methods that can improve the performance of information storage systems based upon magnetic recording and/or solid-state memories. Among our findings are improved detection algorithms for multihead, multitrack magnetic recording, codes to mitigate intercell interference effects in flash memory, constructions of write-once-memory codes that allow rewriting without erasing in flash memories, error-correction codes for racetrack memories, codes for endurance-limited memories, and so-called cooling codes that help with power consumption and thermal management in high-performance interconnects with on-chip memories.

Finally, with the advent of cloud services in recent years, distributed storage is becoming an important data storage architecture. Our research also yielded coding techniques that can efficiently combat the types of errors observed in distributed storage systems. Specifically, we developed an explicit construction of codes that minimize the amount of data stored per node as well as the bandwidth needed to repair a failed node. We also developed and analyzed properties of array-based erasure codes that allow for local recovery from various patterns of multiple node failures. Finally, we developed codes for private information retrieval that reduce the storage overhead without sacrificing communication complexity.
